word.entryDescription: to pay attention to something
word.entryExample: It’s important to take note of the fact that right now the growth in travel consists to a greater extent of non-work related trips.

word.entryDescription: to remove an item of clothing
word.entryExample: Take off your coat and put it in the cupboard.

word.entryDescription: (of an aircraft) to start flying
word.entryExample: We missed the last call for our flight and the plane took off without us.

word.entryDescription: to remove something from a place
word.entryExample: Could you take out the washing from the washing machine when it finishes?

word.entryDescription: to be involved in something with other people
word.entryExample: Do you take part in team sports?

word.entryDescription: to happen
word.entryExample: Have you joined any clubs and if so where do the meetings take place?

word.entryDescription: to go by stairs
word.entryExample: Do you take the stairs rather than the lift?

word.entryDescription: to bring a child or a thing to school
word.entryExample: My father takes me to school every day.

word.entryDescription: to start to do an activity that you did not do before, e.g a new hobby or sport
word.entryExample: You can join a gym or take up a new sport, such as tennis or football.

word.entryDescription: a meal prepared at a restaurant or shop that you take somewhere else to eat, or the place that prepares these meals
word.entryExample: In the west, people often eat takeaways or in restaurants.

word.entryDescription: a performance, in which people compete to show how well they can sing, dance, play a musical instrument, etc
word.entryExample: Rachel and Lucy won the talent show playing their guitars.

word.entryDescription: able to do something very well, often because of natural ability
word.entryExample: I think Robert de Niro was the most talented of all the actors there – that's why he won an Oscar.

word.entryDescription: to say words or have a conversation
word.entryExample: Kim is talking to Lucy.

word.entryDescription: a tall person, tree or building is greater in height than other people, trees or buildings
word.entryExample: There is a tall tree outside our house.

word.entryDescription: a container in which a liquid or gas is stored
word.entryExample: I've been a shark tank cleaner for eight weeks now.

word.entryDescription: a device that you use to turn on or off the supply of water
word.entryExample: Please turn off the tap after use!

word.entryDescription: a large, hairy spider that lives in warm regions
word.entryExample: Most species of tarantulas are not dangerous to humans.

word.entryDescription: to aim an attack at a particular object, place, or person
word.entryExample: The missiles were targeted at our country.

word.entryDescription: a piece of work that has to be done
word.entryExample: Read the task very carefully.

word.entryDescription: to recognize flavours in food and drink
word.entryExample: We taste with our mouth, which tells us if something is sweet or salty, hot or cold and if we like it or not.

word.entryDescription: having a pleasant flavour
word.entryExample: As the food was so tasty we didn't really mind that the service was a bit slow at times.

word.entryDescription: a permanent picture or writing on the skin that has been made with a needle and ink
word.entryExample: Molly's mother was furious when she came home with a tattoo.

word.entryDescription: a car with a driver who you pay to take you somewhere
word.entryExample: I need to get a taxi.

word.entryDescription: someone whose job is to drive a taxi
word.entryExample: If you're lost, ask a taxi driver the way.

word.entryDescription: a hot drink made from dried leaves
word.entryExample: The British drink a lot of tea.

word.entryDescription: (past simple and past participle: 'taught') to give lessons or knowledge to others
word.entryExample: This is my grandpa who taught me how to fish.

word.entryDescription: someone whose job is to teach in a school
word.entryExample: Ms Black is our English teacher.

word.entryDescription: a group of people who play a sport or game against another group
word.entryExample: I am playing in the school football team.

word.entryDescription: different forms of integrating a group of people, which help them enhance social relations and clarify team members’ roles, as well as solve tasks and interpersonal problems that affect team functioning
word.entryExample: Who does not agree that team games are good for team building?

word.entryDescription: a round closed container with a lid and an open pipe, used to serve tea
word.entryExample: The teapot is in the kitchen.

word.entryDescription: to damage something by pulling it apart
word.entryExample: I can assure you the jeans were not torn when I bought them and must be faulty to tear like that.

word.entryDescription: to damage a tendon (a thick strong string-like part of your body that joins a muscle to a bone)
word.entryExample: Oh, it hurts so much! I must have torn my tendon.

word.entryDescription: help or information that you receive from a company when you are using their computers or other products
word.entryExample: I like the fact that I get technical support with my tablet.

word.entryDescription: a soft toy bear
word.entryExample: Lucy likes to play with her teddy.

word.entryDescription: boring, often in an annoying way
word.entryExample: Don't you find all this golf on TV rather tedious?

word.entryDescription: a person between the ages of 13 and 19
word.entryExample: I didn't know that teenagers weren't good at recognising emotions.

word.entryDescription: somebody who does not drink alcohol
word.entryExample: As a teetotaller Brian frowned on what he saw as his colleagues' excessive drinking.

word.entryDescription: a device used to show programmes and films, usually for entertainment at home
word.entryExample: The television is in the living room.

word.entryDescription: to say something to someone, usually giving details or information
word.entryExample: Can you tell me your name?

word.entryDescription: to say someone about something, usually giving details or information
word.entryExample: Patrick, please show your poster to the class and tell them about the festival.

word.entryDescription: to angrily tell somebody that you do not like their behaviour; to scold somebody
word.entryExample: He gets told off at school for being late.

word.entryDescription: (of a climate) characterized by moderate temperatures; neither hot nor cold
word.entryExample: There are five main types of climate: cold, dry, temperate, polar and tropical.

word.entryDescription: a building used by people of certain religions but not Christians or Muslims
word.entryExample: The Parthenon, was both a temple and a treasury for the city's money.

word.entryDescription: the number 10
word.entryExample: There are ten children in my class.

word.entryDescription: a sport played on a court in which two or four people use rackets to hit a small ball over a net
word.entryExample: My parents love playing tennis.

word.entryDescription: unable to relax because of worry or stress
word.entryExample: Modern lives are stressful and tense.

word.entryDescription: a cloth shelter that you can carry with you and put up when you want to stay somewhere
word.entryExample: I slept in a tent on holiday.

word.entryDescription: in the position of number ten when we count
word.entryExample: The office is on the tenth floor.

word.entryDescription: one of a row of houses which are connected together
word.entryExample: I live in a small terraced house.

word.entryDescription: a small model of a person made of terracota (reddish-brown clay that has been baked but not glazed); frequently found in Ancient Greece; used as religious offerings
word.entryExample: Terracotta figurines show women in mysterious headdresses.
